question: Which material is recyclable, biodegradable, and inexpensive?

content.source_1: Paper and paperboard (including corrugated cardboard and molded fiber) are among the most recycled packaging materials worldwide, with high curbside acceptance and recovery rates.
content.source_2: Paper-based packaging such as corrugated cardboard and molded pulp is biodegradable and can break down within months under aerobic conditions (e.g., industrial composting).
content.source_3: Standard corrugated cartons are mass-produced from abundant recycled fiber; high-speed die-cutting and folding lines make corrugated boxes one of the lowest-cost packaging formats per unit.
content.source_4: Molded pulp (formed fiber) is made from recycled paper, is recyclable with paper streams in many municipalities, and is compostable/biodegradable.
content.source_5: For shaped trays and protective inserts, molded pulp integrates cushioning and form into a single piece, eliminating separate corrugated components and assembly, which can lower total unit cost at high volumes.
content.source_6: Molded pulp requires dedicated molds and wet-forming steps that slow production and add tooling expense, so for general-purpose cartons corrugated typically remains the cheaper option.
